Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Is John not yet arrived?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: We expect him at any moment, dearest.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: The girls--I have left so little.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Shh, hush, Henry.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Elinor will try to look after you all, but make sure she finds a good husband. The men are such noodles hereabouts, little wonder none has pleased her.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: But Marianne is sure to find her storybook hero.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: A romantic poet with flashing eyes and empty pockets?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: As long as she loves him, whoever he is.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Margaret will go to sea and become a pirate so we need not concern ourselves with her.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Your son is arrived from London, sir.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Let me speak to John alone.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Ah, my dear. How happy you have made me.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Father...

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: John you will find out soon enough from my will that the estate of Norland was left to me in such a way as prevents me from dividing it between my families.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Calm yourself, Father. This is not good for you.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Norland in its entirety is therefore yours by law and I am happy for you and Fanny.

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: But your stepmother my wife and daughters are left with only five hundred pounds a year, barely enough to live on and nothing for the girls' dowries. You must help them.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Of course

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: You must promise to do this.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I promise, Father, I promise.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Come! Come quickly!

Speaker: mr dashwood
Dialogue: Help them.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: What do you mean, 'help them'?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Dearest, I mean to give them three thousand pounds.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: The interest will provide them with a little extra income. Such a gift will certainly discharge my promise to my father.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Oh, without question! More than amply...

Speaker: john
Dialogue: One had rather, on such occasions, do too much than too little.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Of course, he did not stipulate a particular sum.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: To be reduced to the condition of visitor in my own home! It is not to be borne, Elinor!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Consider, Mamma! We have nowhere to go.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: John and Fanny will descend from London at any moment, followed no doubt by cartloads of relatives ready to turn us out of our rooms one by one do you expect me to be here to welcome them? Vultures!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I shall start making inquiries for a new house at once. Until then we must try to bear their coming.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Fifteen hundred then. What say you to fifteen hundred?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: What brother on earth would do half so much for his real sisters--let alone half-blood?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: They can hardly expect more.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: There is no knowing what they expect. The question is, what can you afford?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, cannot you play something else? Mamma has been weeping since breakfast.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I meant something less mournful, dearest.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: A hundred pounds a year to their mother while she lives. Would that be more advisable? It is better than parting with the fifteen hundred all at once.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: But if she should live longer than fifteen years we would be completely taken in. People always live forever when there is an annuity to be paid them.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Margaret, are you there? Please come down. John and Fanny will be here soon.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Because houses go from father to son, dearest not from father to daughter. It is the law.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: If you come inside, we could play with your atlas.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Twenty pounds now and then will amply discharge my promise, you are quite right.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Indeed. Although to say the truth, I am convinced within myself that your father had no idea of your giving them money.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: They will have five hundred a year amongst them as it is--

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: --and what on earth can four women want for more than that? Their housekeeping will be nothing at all they will have no carriage, no horses, hardly any servants and will keep no company. Only conceive how comfortable they will be!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: As you know, we are looking for a new home. When we leave we shall be able to retain only Thomas and Betsy.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We are very sorry to have to leave you all. But we are certain you will find the new Mrs Dashwood a fair and generous mistress.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: So we are agreed. No money but the occasional gift of game and fish in season will be very welcome.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Your father would be proud of you.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: How is Mrs Ferrars?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: My mother is always in excellent health, thank you. My brother Robert is in town with her this season and quite the most popular bachelor in London! He has his own barouche.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You have two brothers, have you not?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Indeed, yes. Edward is the eldest Mamma quite depends upon him. He is traveling up from Plymouth shortly and will break his journey here.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: If that is agreeable to you, of course.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: My dear John this is your home now.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Fanny wishes to know where the key for the silver cabinet is kept.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Betsy has it, I think. What does Fanny want with the silver?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I can only presume she wants to count it. What are you doing?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Presents for the servants. Have you seen Margaret? I am worried about her. She has taken to hiding in the oddest places.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Fortunate girl. At least she can escape Fanny, which is more than any of us is able.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You do your best. You have not said a word to her for a week.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I have! I have said 'yes' and 'no'.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Good morning, Fanny.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Good morning, Marianne.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: How did you find the silver? Is it all genuine?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Pray, when may we expect the pleasure of your brother's company?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Edward is due tomorrow. And my dear Mrs Dashwood, in view of the fact that he will not be with us for long, I wondered if Miss Margaret would mind giving up her room to him the view is quite incomparable from her windows and I should so much like Edward to see Norland at its best.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Intolerable woman!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: There is but one consolation if Edward is anything like Fanny, we shall be only too happy to leave.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: But where is Miss Margaret? I declare, Mrs Dashwood, I am beginning to doubt of her existence! She must run positively wild!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Forgive us, Mr Ferrars. My youngest is not to be found this morning. She is a little shy of strangers at present.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Naturally. I am also shy of strangers and I have nothing like her excuse.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: How do you like your view, Mr Ferrars?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Very much. Your stables are very handsome and beautifully kept, Mrs Dashwood.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Stables! Edward--your windows overlook the lake.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: An oversight, Fanny, led me to the wrong room. I have rectified the situation and am happily settled in the guest quarters.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: They are all exceedingly spoilt, I find. Miss Margaret spends all her time up trees and under furniture and I have barely had a civil word from Marianne.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: My dear Fanny, they have just lost their father their lives will never be the same again.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: That is no excuse.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: I have never liked the smell of books.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Oh? No. The dust, perhaps.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I hear you have great plans for the walnut grove.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Oh yes! I shall have it pulled down to make room for a Grecian temple.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: How picturesque. Will you show me the site?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Too expensive. We do not need four bedrooms, we can share.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: This one, then?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, we have only five hundred pounds a year. I will send out more inquiries today.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Pardon my intrusion, but I believe I have found what you are looking for.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Oh, Miss Dashwood! Excuse me I was wondering do you by any chance have such a thing as a reliable atlas?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I believe so.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Excellent. I wish to check the position of the Nile.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: My sister says it is in South America.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Oh! No, no indeed. She is quite wrong. For I believe it is in--in Belgium.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Belgium? Surely not. You must be thinking of the Volga.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: The Volga?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Of course. The Volga, which, as you know, starts in...

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Vladivostok, and ends in...

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: St Albans.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Indeed. Where the coffee beans come from.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: The source of the Nile is in Abyssinia.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Is it? Good heavens. How do you do. Edward Ferrars.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Margaret Dashwood.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: That was my father's favourite.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Thank you so much for your help with Margaret, Mr Ferrars. She is a changed girl since your arrival.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Not at all. I enjoy her company.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Has she shown you her tree-house?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Not yet. Would you do me the honour, Miss Dashwood? It is very fine out.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: With pleasure.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Margaret has always wanted to travel.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I know. She is heading an expedition to China shortly. I am to go as her servant but only on the understanding that I will be very badly treated.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: What will your duties be?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Sword-fighting, administering rum and swabbing.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: All I want--all I have ever wanted is the quiet of a private life but my mother is determined to see me distinguished.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: As?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: She hardly knows. Any fine figure will suit a great orator, a leading politician, even a barrister would serve, but only on the condition that I drive my own barouche and dine in the first circles.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: And what do you wish for?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I always preferred the church, but that is not smart enough for my mother she prefers the army, but that is a great deal too smart for me.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Would you stay in London?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I hate London. No peace. A country living is my ideal a small parish where I might do some good, keep chickens and give very short sermons.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You talk of feeling idle and useless imagine how that is compounded when one has no choice and no hope whatsoever of any occupation.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Our circumstances are therefore precisely the same.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Except that you will inherit your fortune.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We cannot even earn ours.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Perhaps Margaret is right.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Right?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Piracy is our only option.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: What is swabbing exactly?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: No voice divine the storm allayed No light propitious shone, When snatched from all effectual aid, We perished each alone: But I beneath a rougher sea, And whelmed in deeper gulfs than he.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No, Edward! Listen.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Can you not feel his despair? Try again.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Mamma, look. This has just arrived.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: 'I should be pleased to offer you a home at Barton Cottage as soon as ever you have need of it' why, it is from my cousin, Sir John Middleton!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Even Elinor must approve the rent.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Has Elinor not yet seen this?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No I will fetch her.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Wait. No. Let us delay.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I think--I believe that Edward and Elinor have formed an attachment.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: It would be cruel to take her away so soon and Devonshire is so far.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Why so grave? Do you disapprove her choice?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: By no means. Edward is very amiable.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Amiable but?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But there is something wanting. He is too sedate his reading last night.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Elinor has not your feelings, his reserve suits her.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Can he love her? Can the ardour of the soul really be satisfied with such polite, concealed affections? To love is to burn to be on fire, all made of passion, of adoration, of sacrifice! Like Juliet, or Guinevere or Heloise.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: They made rather pathetic ends, dear.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Pathetic! To die for love? How can you say so? What could be more glorious?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I think that may be taking your romantic sensibilities a little far.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: The more I know of the world, the more I am convinced that I shall never see a man whom I can truly love.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: You require so much!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I do not! I require only what any young woman of taste should a man who sings well, dances admirably, rides bravely, reads with passion and whose tastes agree in every point with my own.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Is love a fancy, or a feeling? No It is immortal as immaculate truth 'Tis not a blossom shed as soon as Youth Drops from the stem of life for it will grow In barren regions, where no waters flow Nor ray of promise cheats the pensive gloom--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: What a pity it is that Edward has no passion for reading.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: It was you who asked him to read and then you made him nervous.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: But your behaviour to him in all other respects is perfectly cordial so I must assume that you like him in spite of his deficiencies.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I think him everything that is amiable and worthy.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Praise indeed!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But he shall have my unanswering devotion when you tell me he is to be my brother.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: How shall I do without you?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Do without me?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I am sure you will be very happy. But you must promise not to live too far away.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, there is no question of that is, there is no under standing between...

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Do you love him?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I do not attempt to deny that I think very highly of him that I greatly esteem that I like him.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Esteem him! Like him! Use those insipid words again and I shall leave the room this instant!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Very well. Forgive me. Believe my feelings to be stronger than I have declared but further than that you must not believe.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: 'Is love a fancy or a feeling?' Or a Ferrars?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Go to bed!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: 'I do not attempt to deny that I think highly of him greatly esteem him! Like him!'

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: We are all so happy that you chose to invite Edward to Norland. He is a dear boy and we are all very fond of him.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: We have great hopes for him. Much is expected of him by our mother with regard to his profession

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Naturally.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: And in marriage. She is determined that both he and Robert will marry well.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Of course. But I hope she desires them to marry for love, first and foremost? I have always felt that, contrary to common wisdom, true affection is by far the most valuable dowry.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Love is all very well, but unfortunately we cannot always rely on the heart to lead us in the most suitable directions.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: You see, my dear Mrs Dashwood, Edward is entirely the kind of compassionate person upon whom penniless women can prey--and having entered into any kind of understanding, he would never go back on his word. He is quite simply incapable of doing so. But it would lead to his ruin. I worry for him so, Mrs Dashwood. My mother has always made it perfectly plain that she will withdraw all financial support from Edward, should he choose to plant his affections in less... exalted ground than he deserves.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I understand you perfectly.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Devonshire!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: My cousin Sir John Middleton has offered us a small house on his estate.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Sir John Middleton? What is his situation? He must be a man of property.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: He is a widower. He lives with his mother-in-law at Barton Park and it is Barton Cottage that he offers us.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Oh, a cottage! How charming. A little cottage is always very snug.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: But you will not leave before the summer?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Oh, my dear Edward, we can no longer trespass upon your sister's good will. We must leave as soon as possible.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: You will come and stay with us, Edward!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I should like that very much.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Edward has long been expected in town by our mother.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Come as soon as you can, Edward. Remember that you are always welcome.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Cannot you take him with you?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We cannot possibly afford him.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Perhaps he could make himself useful in the kitchen?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Miss Dashwood--Elinor. I must talk to you.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: There is something of great importance I need... to tell you--

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: --about--about my education.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Your education?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Yes. It was less... successful than it might have been.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: It was conducted in Plymouth--oddly enough.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Indeed?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Yes. Do you know it?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Plymouth?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Oh--well--I spent four years there-- at a school run by a--a Mr Pratt--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Pratt?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Precisely--Mr Pratt--and there, I-- that is to say, he has a--

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Edward! Edward!

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: I have been all over for you! You are needed in London this instant!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Fanny, I am leaving this afternoon as it is--

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: No, no, that will not do. Family affairs are in chaos owing to your absence. Mother is quite adamant that you should leave at once.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Excuse me, Miss Dashwood.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Edward promised he would bring the atlas to Barton for me.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Did he? Well, I will wager he will do so in less than a fortnight!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Sir John!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Dear ladies, dear ladies, upon my word, here you are, here you are, here you are!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Sir John, your extraordinary kindness--

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Oh, none of that, hush, please, none of that, but here is my dear mamma- in-law Mrs Jennings.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Was the journey tolerable, you poor souls?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Why did you not come up to the Park first and take your ease? We saw you pass--Like many people who live rather lonely lives together.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: --but I would not wait for you to come to us, I made John call for the carriage--

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: She would not wait, you know.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: --as we get so little company.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: --call--and here is Miss Marianne!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Where did you disappear to?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I declare you are the loveliest girl I ever set eyes on! Cannot you get them married, Mrs Dashwood? You must not leave it too long!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: But, alas, there are no smart young men hereabouts to woo them--

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: --not a beau for miles!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Come, Mother, let us leave them in peace.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: But there is Colonel Brandon!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Excellent fellow! We served in the East India Regiment together.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Just wait till he sees you! If we can persuade him out to meet you!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Reclusive individual. But you are fatigued. I can see that you are fatigued.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Of course she is fatigued!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Come along, Mother, we really must leave them to themselves.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: You must get your maidservant to make you up some camphor--it is the best tonic for the staggers!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Send Thomas to us for the carriage when you are ready!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I like them.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: What generosity.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Indeed. I am surprised they did not offer us their clothing.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Sugar is five shilling a pound these parts, Miss Dashwood.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No more sugar then.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon is the most eligible bachelor in the county--he is bound to do for one of you. Mind, he is a better age for Miss Dashwood--but I dare say she left her heart behind in Sussex, eh?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Aha! I see you, Miss Marianne! I think I have unearthed a secret!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Oho! Have you sniffed one out already, Mother? You are worse than my best pointer, Flossie!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: What sort of man is he, Miss Dashwood? Is he butcher, baker, candlestick- maker? I shall winkle it out of you somehow, you know!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: She's horribly good at winkling.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: You are in lonely country now, Miss Dashwood, none of us has any secrets here--

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: --or if we do, we do not keep them for long!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: He is curate of the parish, I dare say!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Or a handsome lieutenant!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Give us a clue, Miss Dashwood--is he in uniform?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: He has no profession!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: No profession! A gentleman, then!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Margaret, you know perfectly well there is no such person.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: There is! There is! And his name begins with an F!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Margaret!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: F indeed! A very promising letter. Let me--F, F, Fo, Fa... Upon my word, but I cannot think of a single name beginning with F--

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Forrest? Foster? Frost? Foggarty?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Sir John, might I play your pianoforte?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Of course, yes--my goodness. We do not stand on ceremony here, my dear.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Brandon! Where have you been? Come, come and meet our beautiful new neighbours!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: What a pity you are late, Colonel! You have missed the most delightful singing!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: A great pity, indeed.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Mrs Dashwood, may I present my dear friend Colonel Brandon? We served together in the East Indies and I assure you there is no better fellow on earth--

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Have you really been to the East Indies, Colonel?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I have.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: What is it like?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Like? Hot.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: The air is full of spices.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Come, Miss Dashwood--it is your turn to entertain us!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Oh no, Sir John, I do not--

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: --and I think we can all guess what key you will sing in!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: As for you, you have no right, no right at all, to parade your ignorant assumptions--

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: They are not assumptions. You told me.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I told you nothing--

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: They'll meet him when he comes, anyway.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: That is not the point. You do not speak of such things before strangers--

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: But everyone else was--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Mrs Jennings is not everyone.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I like her! She talks about things. We never talk about things.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Hush, please, now that is enough, Margaret. If you cannot think of anything appropriate to say, you will please restrict your remarks to the weather.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I like Colonel Brandon too. He's been to places.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: You know what they're saying, of course...

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: The word is that you have developed a taste for--certain company.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: And why not, say I. A man like you-- in his prime--she'd be a most fortunate young lady--

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Marianne Dashwood would no more think of me than she would of you, John.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Brandon, my boy, do not think of yourself so meanly--

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: And all the better for her.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Besotted! Excellent match, for he is rich and she is handsome.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: How long have you known the Colonel?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Oh, Lord bless you, as long as ever I have been here, and I came fifteen years back. His estate at Delaford is but four miles hence and he and John are very thick. He has no wife or children of his own, for--

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: --he has a tragic history. He loved a girl once--twenty years ago now--a ward to his family, but they were not permitted to marry...

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: On what grounds?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Money. Eliza was poor. When the father discovered their amour, she was flung out of the house and he packed off into the army. I believe he would have done himself a harm if not for John...

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: What became of the lady?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Oh, she was passed from man to man-- disappeared from all good society. When Brandon got back from India he searched for heaven knows how long, only to find her dying in a poor house. You have seen how it has affected him. Once I thought my daughter Charlotte might have cheered him up, but she is much better off where she is.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Look at him now, though. So attentive. I shall try an experiment on him.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Oh no, please, dear Mrs Jennings, leave the poor Colonel alone.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: No, no, it is just the thing--all suitors need a little help, my dear

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: We have not heard you play for us of late!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: For the simple reason that you have a far superior musician here.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Perhaps you did not know, Miss Marianne, that our dear Brandon shares your passion for music and plays the piano forte very well.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Play us a duet!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I'll trow you know quite as many melancholy tunes as Miss Marianne!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Come! Let us see you both side by side!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I do not know any duets. Forgive me, Colonel.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Oh! Are we never to have a moment's peace? The rent here may be low but I think we have it on very hard terms.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mrs Jennings is a wealthy woman with a married daughter--she has nothing to do but marry off everyone else's.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: There's a parcel arrived for you, Miss Dashwood!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: A parcel!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: It is too ridiculous! When is a man to be safe from such wit if age and infirmity do not protect him?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Infirmity!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: If Colonel Brandon is infirm, then I am at death's door.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: It is a miracle your life has extended this far...

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Did you not hear him complain of a rheumatism in his shoulder?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: A slight ache' I believe was his phrase...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: But Edward said he would bring it himself.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: 'Dear Mrs Dashwood, Miss Dashwood, Miss Marianne and Captain Margaret-- it gives me great pleasure to restore this atlas to its rightful owner. Alas, business in London does not permit me to accompany it, although this is likely to hurt me far more than it hurts you. For the present my memories of your kindness must be enough to sustain me, and I remain your devoted servant always. E. C. Ferrars.'

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: But why hasn't he come?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: He says he is busy, dear.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: He said he'd come.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Why hasn't he come?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I am taking you for a walk.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: No! I've been a walk.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: You need another.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: It is going to rain.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: It is not going to rain.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: You always say that and then it always does.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I fear Mrs Jennings is a bad influence.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: You must miss him, Elinor.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We are not engaged, Mamma.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: But he loves you, dearest, of that I am certain.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I am by no means assured of his regard for me.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Oh, Elinor!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: But even were he to feel such a... preference, I think we should be foolish to assume that there would not be many obstacles to his choosing a woman of no rank who cannot afford to buy sugar...

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: But Elinor--your heart must tell you--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: In such a situation, Mamma, it is perhaps better to use one's head.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Is there any felicity in the world superior to this?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I told you it would rain.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Look! There is some blue sky! Let us chase it!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I'm not supposed to run.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Marianne!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Help me!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Margaret, run home and fetch help.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I think it is this way. I will run as fast as I can, Marianne.

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: Are you hurt?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Only my ankle.

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: May I have your permission to--

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: --ascertain if there are any breaks?

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: It is not broken. Now, can you put your arm about my neck?

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: Allow me to escort you home.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Marianne was sure it would not rain.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Which invariably means it will.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: At last!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: She fell over! She fell down--and he's carrying her!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Marianne!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: In here, sir--this way. Margaret, open the door wider. Please, sir, lay her here. Marianne, are you in pain?

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: It is a twisted ankle.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Do not be alarmed, Mamma.

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: I can assure you it is not serious. I took the liberty of feeling the bone and it is perfectly sound.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Sir, I cannot even begin to thank you.

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: Please do not think of it. I'm honoured of be of service.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Will you not be seated?

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: Pray excuse me--I have no desire to leave a water mark! But permit me to call tomorrow afternoon and inquire after the patient?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: We shall look forward to it!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: His name! His name!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Please tell us to whom we are so much obliged?

Speaker: the stranger
Dialogue: John Willoughby of Allenham--your servant, ma'am!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Mr John Willoughby of Allenham!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: What an impressive gentleman!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: He lifted me as if I weighed no more than a dried leaf!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Is he human?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Tell me if I hurt you.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: She feels no pain, Mamma. Margaret, ask Betsy to make up a cold compress, please.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Did you see him? He expressed himself well, did he not?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: With great decorum and honour.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: And spirit and wit and feeling.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: And economy--ten words at most.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: And he is to come tomorrow!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You must change, Marianne--you will catch a cold.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: What care I for colds when there is such a man?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You will care very much when your nose swells up.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: You are right. Help me, Elinor.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: What has happened?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We have decided to give you to the Gypsies.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Will they be married before Edward and Elinor, do you think, Mamma?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Margaret, you are worse than Mrs Jennings.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But what do you know of Mr Willoughby, Sir John?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Decent shot--and there is not a bolder rider in all England.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But what is he like?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Like?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: What are his tastes? His passions? His pursuits?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Well, he has the nicest little bitch of a pointer--was she out with him yesterday?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Where is Allenham, Sir John?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Nice little estate three miles east. He is to inherit it from an elderly relative--Lady Allen is her name.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: It is Colonel Brandon. I shall go outside and keep watch.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: You are all on the lookout for Willoughby, eh? Dear me, poor Brandon. You will none of you think of him now.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: How is the invalid?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Thank you so much, Colonel.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Miss Marianne, I cannot see why you should set your cap at Mr Willoughby when you have already made such a splendid conquest!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I have no intention of 'setting my cap' at anyone, Sir John!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Mr Willoughby--Lady Allen's nephew?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Aye, he visits every year for he is to inherit Allenham--and he has a very pretty estate of his own, Miss Dashwood, Combe Magna in Somerset. If I were you, I would not give him up to my younger sister in spite of all this tumbling down hills.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: Here is the man himself. Come, Brandon-- we know when we are not wanted. Let us leave him to the ladies!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne! Sir John and the Colonel are leaving.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Goodbye, Colonel. Thank you for the flowers.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: How do you do, Colonel?

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: How does he do? How do you do, more like. Go on in, they're waiting for you!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Mr Willoughby! What a pleasure to see you again!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: The pleasure is all mine, I can asstire you. I trust Miss Marianne has not caught cold?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: You have found out my name!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Of course. The neighbourhood is crawling with my spies.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: And since you cannot venture out to nature, nature must be brought to you!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: How beautiful. These are not from the hothouse.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Ah! I see mine is not the first offering, nor the most elegant. I am afraid I obtained these from an obliging field.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But I have always preferred wild flowers!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: I suspected as much.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I will put these in water.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Our gratitude, Mr Willoughby, is beyond expression--

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: But it is I who am grateful. I have often passed this cottage and grieved for its lonely state--and then the first news I had from Lady Allen when I arrived was that it was taken. I felt a peculiar interest in the event which nothing can account for but my present delight in meeting you.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Pray sit down, Mr Willoughby.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Who is reading Shakespeare's sonnets?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Marianne has been reading them out to us.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Which are your favourites?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Let me not to the marriage of true minds Admit impediments. Love is not love Which alters when it alteration finds, Or bends with the remover to remove--then how does it go?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: '0, no! it is an ever-fixed mark.'

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: 'That looks on storms'--or is it tempests? Let me find it.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: It is strange you should be reading them--for, look, I carry this with me always.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Till tomorrow! And my pocket sonnets are yours, Miss Marianne! A talisman against further injury!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Goodbye! Thank you!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Good work, Marianne! You have covered all forms of poetry; another meeting will ascertain his views on nature and romantic attachments and then you will have nothing left to talk about and the acquaintanceship will be over.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I suppose I have erred against decorum. I should have been dull and spiritless and talked only of the weather, or the state of the roads.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No, but Mr Willoughby can be in no doubt of your enthusiasm for him.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Why should he doubt it? Why should I hide my regard?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No particular reason, Marianne, only that we know so little of him--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But time alone does not determine intimacy. Seven years would be insufficient to make some people acquainted with each other and seven days are more than enough for others.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Or seven hours in this case.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I feel I know Mr Willoughby well already. If I had weaker, more shallow feelings perhaps I could conceal them, as you do--

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Marianne, that is not fair--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I am sorry, Elinor, I did not mean

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I know. Do not trouble yourself, Marianne.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I do not understand her, Mamma. Why does she never mention Edward? I have never even seen her cry about him, or about Norland.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Nor I. But Elinor is not like you or I, dear. She does not like to be swayed by her emotions.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Surely you are not going to deny us beef as well as sugar?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: There is nothing under tenpence a pound. We have to economise.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Do you want us to starve?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No. Just not to eat beef.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: If there was any true impropriety in my behaviour, I should be sensible of it, Elinor--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: But as it has already exposed you to some very impertinent remarks, do you not begin to doubt your own discretion?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: If the impertinent remarks of such as Mrs Jennings are proof of impropriety, then we are all offending every moment of our lives--

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Miss Dashwood! Miss Marianne!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Good morning, Colonel!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I come to issue an invitation. A picnic on my estate at Delaford--if you would care to join us on Thursday next. Mrs Jennings's daughter and her husband are traveling up especially.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Thank you, Colonel, we shall be delighted.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I will of course be including Mr Willoughby in the party.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I should be delighted to join you, Colonel!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Good morning, Miss Dashwood; good morning, Colonel.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: The Colonel has invited us to Delaford, Willoughby!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Excellent. I understand you have a particularly fine pianoforte, Colonel.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: A Broadwood Grand.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: A Broadwood Grand! Then I shall really be able to play for you!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: We shall look forward to it!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Your sister seems very happy.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Yes. Marianne does not approve of hiding her emotions. In fact, her romantic prejudices have the unfortunate tendency to set propriety at naught.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: She is wholly unspoilt.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Rather too unspoilt, in my view. The sooner she becomes acquainted with the ways of the world, the better.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I knew a lady like your sister--the same impulsive sweetness of temper-- who was forced into, as you put it, a better acquaintance with the world. The result was only ruination and despair.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Do not desire it, Miss Dashwood.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Imagine my surprise, Mrs Dashwood, when Charlotte and her lord and master appeared with our cousin Lucy! The last person I expected to see! 'Where did you pop out from, Miss?' says I. I was never so surprised to see anyone in all my life!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: She probably came on purpose to share the fun, for there are no funds for such luxuries at home, poor thing.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I had not seen you for so long, dear Mrs Jennings, I could not resist the opportunity.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Oh, you sly thing! It was the Misses Dashwood she wanted to see, not Delaford, Mamma! I have heard nothing but 'Miss Dashwood this, Miss Dashwood that' for I don't know how long! And what do you think of them now you do see them, Lucy? My mother has talked of nothing else in her letters since you came to Barton, Mrs Dashwood. Mr Palmer--are they not the very creatures she describes?

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: Nothing like.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Why, Mr Palmer! Do you know you are quite rude today? He is to be an MP, you know, Mrs Dashwood, and it is very fatiguing for him for he is forced to make everybody like him-- he says it is quite shocking--

Speaker: mrs palmer
Dialogue: I never said anything so irrational. Don't palm all your abuses of the language upon me.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Mr Palmer is so droll--he is always out of humour.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Here he is! Now you shall see, Charlotte.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: How now, Mr Willoughby! You must greet my daughter Charlotte, and Mr Palmer--

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: And my little cousin, Miss Lucy Steele.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Welcome to our party, Miss Steele!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I know Mr Willoughby extremely well-- not that I ever spoke to him but I have seen him forever in town. Your sister is monstrous lucky to get him. Mamma says Colonel Brandon is in love with her as well, which is a very great compliment for he hardly ever falls in love with anyone.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: May I beg a seat beside you, Miss Dashwood? I have so longed to make your better acquaintance! I have heard nothing but the highest praise for you.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I would be delighted. But Sir John and Mrs Jennings are too excessive in their compliments. I am sure to disappoint.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: No, for it was from quite another source that I heard you praised and one not at all inclined to exaggeration.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: What can this be?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: My horse! Quickly!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: What is the matter, Brandon?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I must away to London.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: No! Impossible!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Imperative.

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: But Brandon, we are all assembled. We cannot picnic at Delaford without our host! Go up to town tomorrow.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Or wait till we return and start then--you would not be six hours later.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I cannot afford to lose one minute.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh, Miss Dashwood, I cannot bear it! Just when I was to have the opportunity of speaking with you.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Frailty, thy name is Brandon!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: There are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure. I think he wrote the letter himself as a trick for getting out of it.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: You are a very wicked pair, Colonel Brandon will be sadly missed.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Why? When he is the kind of man that everyone speaks well of and no one wants to talk to.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Exactly!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Nonsense.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon is very highly esteemed at the Park.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Which is enough censure in itself.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Really, Willoughby!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Come, come, Mr Impudence--I know you and your wicked ways--oh!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Come, Miss Dashwood, reveal your beau, reveal him, I say! Let's have no secrets between friends! Let me winkle them out of you!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: I declare, Miss Marianne, if I do not have you married to the Colonel by teatime, I shall swallow my own bonnet.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: As if you could marry such a character.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Why should you dislike him?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Because he has threatened me with rain when I wanted it fine, he has found fault with the balance of my curricle and I cannot persuade him to buy my brown mare. If it will be of any satisfaction to you, however, to be told I believe his character to be in all other respects irreproachable, I am ready to confess it. And in return for an acknowledgement that must give me some pain.  as much as I adore...

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: --this cottage!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I have great plans for improvements to it, you know, Mr Willoughby.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Now that I will never consent to. Not a stone must be added to its walls. Were I rich enough, I would instantly pull down Combe Magna and build it up again in the exact image of that cottage!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: With dark, narrow stairs, a poky hall and a fire that smokes?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Especially the fire that smokes! Then I might be as happy at Combe Magna as I have been at Barton.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: But this place has one claim on my affection which no other can possibly share.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Promise me you will never change it.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I do not have the heart.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Or the money.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Miss Marianne, will you--will you do me the honour of granting me an interview tomorrow--alone?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Willoughby, we are always alone!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: But there is something very particular I should like to ask you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Of course. I shall ask Mamma if I may stay behind from church.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Thank you. Until tomorrow then--Miss Marianne.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Do you think he will kneel down when he asks her?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Shhh!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: They always kneel down.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: What is wrong, my dearest?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Willoughby! What is the matter?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: I--forgive me, Mrs Dashwood. I am sent--that is to say, Lady Allen has exercised the privilege of riches upon a dependent cousin and is sending me to London.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: When--this morning?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Almost this moment.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: How very disappointing! But your business will not detain you from us for long, I hope?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: You are very kind--but I have no idea of returning immediately to Devonshire. I am seldom invited to Allenham more than once a year.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: For shame, Willoughby! Can you wait for an invitation from Barton Cottage?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: My engagements at present are of such a nature--that is--I dare not flatter myself--

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: It is folly to linger in this manner. I will not torment myself further.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Willoughby, come back!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Meg, dearest, please ask Betsy to make a cup of hot tea for Marianne.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: What is wrong, my love?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Nothing! Please do not ask me questions!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Please let me be!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: They must have quarreled.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: That is unlikely. Perhaps this--Lady Allen--disapproves of his regard for Marianne and has invented an excuse to send him away?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Then why did he not say as much? It is not like Willoughby to be secretive. Did he think Marianne was richer than she is?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: How could he?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: What is it you suspect him of?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I can hardly tell you. But why was his manner so guilty?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: What are you saying, Elinor? That he has been acting a part to your sister for all this time?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No, he loves her, I am sure.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Of course he loves her!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: But has he left her with any assurance of his return? Cannot you ask her if he has proposed?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Certainly not. I cannot force a confidence from Marianne and nor must you. We must trust her to confide in us in her own time.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: There was something so underhand in the manner of his leaving.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: You are resolved, then, to think the worst of him.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Not resolved--

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I prefer to give him the benefit of my good opinion. He deserves no less. From all of us.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mamma, I am very fond of Willoughby--

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: She would not let me in.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: How like a winter hath my absence been from thee, the pleasure of the fleeting year! What freezings have I felt, what dark days seen! What old December's bareness everywhere!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Oh! If only this rain would stop!

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: If only you would stop.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: 'Twas you took her off my hands, Mr Palmer, and a very good bargain you made of it too, but now I have the whip hand over you for you cannot give her back!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Miss Marianne, come and play a round with us! Looking out at the weather will not bring him back.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: She ate nothing at dinner.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Mind, we are all a little forlorn these days. London has swallowed all our company.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Dear Miss Dashwood, perhaps now we might have our--discussion.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Our discussion?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: There is a particular question I have long wanted to ask you, but perhaps you will think me impertinent?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I cannot imagine so.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: But it is an odd question. Forgive me, I have no wish to trouble you--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: My dear Miss Steele--

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Miss Dashwood, if only Mr Willoughby had gone home to Combe Magna, we could have taken Miss Marianne to see him! For we live but half a mile away.

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: Five and a half.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: No, I cannot believe it is that far, for you can see the place from the top of our hill. Is it really five and a half miles? No! I cannot believe it.

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: Try.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You have my permission to ask any manner of question, if that is of any help.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Thank you. I wonder, are you at all acquainted with your sister-in-law's mother? Mrs Ferrars?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: With Fanny's mother? No, I have never met her.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I am sure you think me strange for inquiring--if I dared tell--

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: If she tells you aught of the famous 'Mr F', Lucy, you are to pass it on.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Will you take a turn with me, Miss Dashwood?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I had no idea at all that you were connected with that family.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh! I am certainly nothing to Mrs Ferrars at present--but the time may come when we may be very intimately connected.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: What do you mean? Do you have an understanding with Fanny's brother Robert?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: The youngest? No, I never saw him in my life. No, with Edward.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Edward?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Edward Ferrars?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Edward and I have been secretly engaged these five years.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: You may well be surprised. I should never have mentioned it, had I not known I could entirely trust you to keep our secret. Edward cannot mind me telling you for he looks on you quite as his own sister.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I am sorry, but we surely--we cannot mean the same Mr Ferrars?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: The very same--he was four years under the tutelage of my uncle Mr Pratt, down in Plymouth. Has he never spoken of it?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Pratt! Yes, I believe he has.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I was very unwilling to enter into it without his mother's approval but we loved each other with too great a passion for prudence. Though you do nor know him so well as I, Miss Dashwood, you must have seen how capable he is of making a woman sincerely attached to him. I cannot pretend it has not been very hard on us both. We can hardly meet above twice a year.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: You seem out of sorts, Miss Dashwood-- are you quite well?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Perfectly well, thank you.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I have not offended you?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: On the contrary.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I can stand it no longer, I must know what you are saying, Lucy! Miss Dashwood is quite engrossed!

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh, Miss Dashwood, if anyone finds out, it will ruin him--you must not tell a soul! Edward says you would not break your word to save your life! Promise me!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I give you my word.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Well, what can have fascinated you to such an extent, Miss Dashwood?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Tell us all!

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: We were talking of London, ma'am, and all its--diversions.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Do you hear, Charlotte?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: While you were so busy whispering, Charlotte and I have concocted a plan!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: It is the best plan in the world.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I make for London shortly and I invite you, Lucy, and both the Misses Dashwood to join me!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: London!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Oh, can I go! Can I go?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: You know perfectly well you are too young, dearest.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I shall convey you all to my house in Berkeley Street and we shall taste all the delights of the season--what say you?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Oh, please can I go? I'm twelve soon.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Mr Palmer, do you not long to have the Misses Dashwood come to London?

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: I came into Devonshire with no other view.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mrs Jennings, you are very kind, but we cannot possibly leave our mother...

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Indeed, the loss would be too great.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Your mother can spare you very well.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Of course I can!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Of course she can!

Speaker: sir john
Dialogue: And look at Miss Marianne--it would break her heart to deny her!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I will brook no refusal, Miss Dashwood!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Let you and me strike hands upon the bargain--and if I do not have the three of you married by Christmas, it will not be my fault!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I was never so grateful in all my life as I am to Mrs Jennings. What a kind woman she is! I like her more than I can say. Oh, Elinor! I shall see Willoughby. Think how surprised he will be! And you will see Edward!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Are you asleep?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: With you in the room?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I do not believe you feel as calm as you look, not even you, Elinor. I will never sleep tonight! Oh, what were you and Miss Steele whispering about so long?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Nothing of significance.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I have written to Edward, Miss Dashwood, and yet I do not know how much I may see of him. Secrecy is vital--he will never be able to call.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I should imagine not.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: It is so hard. I believe my only comfort has been the constancy of his affection.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You are fortunate, over such a lengthy engagement, never to have had any doubts on that score.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh! I am of rather a jealous nature and if he had talked more of one young lady than any other... but he has never given a moment's alarm on that count.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Imagine how glad he will be to learn that we are friends!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: To be sure, my dear, you must just hand it to Pigeon there. He will take care of it.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Lord above, you do not waste any time, Miss Marianne!

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: A letter! So they are definitely engaged! Mrs Jennings says your sister will buy her wedding clothes here in town.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Indeed Miss Steele, I know of no such plan.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: John and Fanny are in town. I think we shall be forced to see them.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I think it was for next door.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Yes, you are right.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Oh, Elinor! It is Willoughby, indeed it is!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Oh! Excuse me, Colonel--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon, what a pleasure to see you! Have you been in London all this while?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I have. How is your dear mother?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Very well, thank you.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Colonel, is there anything--

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Forgive me, Miss Dashwood, but I have heard reports through town... is it impossible to--but I could have no chance of succeeding--indeed I hardly know what to do. Tell me once and for all, is everything finally resolved between your sister and Mr Willoughby?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Colonel, though neither one has informed me of their under standing, I have no doubt of their mutual affection.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Thank you, Miss Dashwood. To your sister I wish all imaginable happiness. To Mr Willoughby, that he... may endeavour to deserve her.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Forgive me, I--forgive me.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Where is dear Edward, John? We expect to see him daily.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: And who is 'dear Edward'?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Who indeed?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: My brother, Mrs Jennings--Edward Ferrars.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Indeed! Is that Ferrars with an F?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Are there any messages, Pigeon?

Speaker: pigeon
Dialogue: No, ma'am.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No message at all? No cards?

Speaker: pigeon
Dialogue: None, ma am.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I note you do not inquire for your messages, Miss Dashwood!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No, for I do not expect any, Mrs Jennings. I have very little acquaintance in town.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: She is as sly as you, Lucy!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, is anything wrong?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Nothing at all. Go back to sleep.

Speaker: pigeon
Dialogue: No messages, ma am.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Do not fret, my dear. I am told that this good weather is keeping many sportsmen in the country at present, but the frost will drive them back to town very soon, depend upon it.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Of course! I had not thought of-- thank you, Mrs Jennings!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: And Miss Dashwood may set her heart at rest, for I overheard your sister- in-law say that she was to bring the elusive Mr F to the ball tonight!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: This is very merry!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: There you are! Goodness, how hot it is, Mrs Dashwood. You are not alone, I trust?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Indeed not. John is just gone to fetch my brother--he has been eating ices.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Your brother! I declare, that is good news indeed. At long last!

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Miss Dashwood, I declare I shall faint clean away.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Mrs Jennings, may I present my brother- in-law?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Mr Robert Ferrars!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: My dear ladies--we meet at last!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: So you must be the younger brother? Is Mr Edward not here? Miss Dashwood here was counting on him!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Oh! He is far too busy for such gatherings--and has no special acquaintance here to make his attendance worthwhile.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Well, I declare, I do not know what the young men are about these days-- are they all in hiding?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Come, Mr Robert, in the absence of your brother, you must dance with our lovely Miss Dashwood!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: It would be my honour.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: And perhaps Miss Steele might consider reserving the allemande?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: You reside in Devonshire, I b'lieve, Miss Dashwood?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We do.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: In a cottage?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I am excessively fond of a cottage. If I had any money to spare, I should build one myself.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: How do you do, Miss Dashwood?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I am well, thank you, Mr Willoughby.

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: How is your--family?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We are all extremely well, Mr Willoughby--thank you for your kind inquiry.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Willoughby!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Good God, Willoughby! Will you nor shake hands with me?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: How do you do, Miss Marianne?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Willoughby, what is the matter? Why have you not come to see me? Were you not in London? Have you nor received my letters?

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Yes, I had the pleasure of receiving the information which you were so good as to send me.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: For heaven's sake, Willoughby, tell me what is wrong!

Speaker: willoughby
Dialogue: Thank you--I am most obliged. If you will excuse me, I must return to my party.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Willoughby!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne! Come away!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Go to him, Elinor--force him to come to me.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Dearest, do not betray what you feel to everyone present! This is not the place for explanations--

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Come along, dear.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Will you come, Lucy?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh, are we leaving so soon?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: If I might be so bold, Mrs Jennings, it would be our pleasure to escort your young charge home.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: How very kind!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: That is very handsome--

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: She actually sent him messages during the night?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, please tell me--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Do not ask me questions!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You have no confidence in me.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: This reproach from you! You, who confide in no one.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I have nothing to tell.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Nor I. We have neither of us anything to tell. I because I conceal nothing and you because you communicate nothing.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: There now! Lovers' quarrels are swift to heal! That letter will do the trick, mark my word.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I must be off. I hope he won't keep her waiting much longer, Miss Dashwood. It hurts to see her looking so forlorn.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: What a welcome I had from Edward's family, Miss Dashwood--I am surprised you never told me what an agreeable woman your sister-in-law is! And Mr Robert--all so affable!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: It is perhaps fortunate that none of them knows of your engagement. Excuse me.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: 'My dear Madam--I am quite at a loss to discover in what point I could be so unfortunate as to offend you. My esteem for your family is very sincere but if I have given rise to a belief of more than I felt or meant to express, I shall reproach myself for not having been more guarded. My affections have long been engaged elsewhere and it is with great regret that I return your letters and the lock of hair which you so obligingly bestowed upon me. I am etc. John Willoughby.'

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Oh, Marianne.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, oh, Marianne--it is better to know at once what his intentions are. Dearest, think of what you would have felt if your engagement had carried on for months and months before he chose to put an end to it.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: We are not engaged.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: But you wrote to him! I thought then that he must have left you with some kind of understanding?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No--he is not so unworthy as you think him.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Not so unworthy! Did he tell you that he loved you?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Yes. No--never absolutely. It was every day implied, but never declared. Sometimes I thought it had been, but it never was. He has broken no vow.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: He has broken faith with all of us, he made us all believe he loved you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: He did! He did--he loved me as I loved him.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: I had to come straight up--how are you, Miss Marianne?

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Poor thing! She looks very bad. No wonder, Miss Dashwood, for it is but too true. I was told here in the street by Miss Morton, who is a great friend: he is to be married at the end of the month--to a Miss Grey with fifty thousand pounds. Well, said I, if 'tis true, then he is a good-for-nothing who has used my young friend abominably ill, and I wish with all my soul that his wife may plague his heart out!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: But he is not the only young man worth having, my dear, and with your pretty face you will never want for admirers.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Ah, me! She had better have her cry out and have done with it. I will go and look out something to tempt her-- does she care for olives?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I cannot tell you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I cannot believe his nature capable of such cruelty!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, there is no excuse for him-- this is his hand--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But it cannot be his heart! Oh, Mamma! I want Mamma! Elinor, please take me home! Cannot we go tomorrow?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: There is no one to take us.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Cannot we hire a carriage?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We have no money--and indeed we owe Mrs Jennings more courtesy.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: All she wants is gossip and she only likes me because I supply it! Oh, God! I cannot endure to stay.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I will find a way. I promise.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Apparently they never were engaged.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Miss Grey has fifty thousand pounds. Marianne is virtually penniless.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: She cannot have expected him to go through with it. But I feel for Marianne--she will lose her bloom and end a spinster like Elinor. I think, my dear, we might consider having them to stay with us for a few days--we are, after all, family, and my father.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: My love, I would ask them with all my heart, but I have already asked Miss Steele for a visit and we cannot deprive Mrs Jennings of all her company at once. We can invite your sisters some other year, you know, and Miss Steele will profit far more from your generosity--poor girl!

Speaker: john
Dialogue: That is very thoughtful, Fanny. We shall ask Elinor and Marianne next year, then... Certainly!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Thank you for coming, Colonel.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: How does your sister?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I must get her home as quickly as possible. The Palmers can take us as far as Cleveland, which is but a day from Barton--

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Then permit me to accompany you and take you straight on from Cleveland to Barton myself.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I confess that is precisely what I had hoped for. Marianne suffers cruelly, and what pains me most is how hard she tries to justify Mr Willoughby. But you know her disposition.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Perhaps I--my regard for you all-- Miss Dashwood, will you allow me to prove it by relating some circumstances which nothing but an earnest desire of being useful--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You have something to tell me of Mr Willoughby.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: When I quitted Barton last--but I must go further back. A short account of myself will be necessary. No doubt... no doubt Mrs Jennings has apprised you of certain events in my past--the sad outcome of my connection with a young woman named Eliza.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: What is not commonly known is that twenty years ago, Eliza bore an illegitimate child. The father, whoever he was, abandoned them.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: As she lay dying, she begged me to look after the child. Eliza died in my arms, broken, wasted away--ah! Miss Dashwood, such a subject-- untouched for so many years--it is dangerous...

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I had failed Eliza in every other way--I could not refuse her now. I took the child--Beth is her name-- and placed her with a family where I could be sure she would be well looked after. I saw her whenever I could. I saw that she was headstrong like her mother--and, God forgive me, I indulged her, I allowed her too much freedom. Almost a year ago, she disappeared.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Disappeared!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I instigated a search but for eight months I was left to imagine the worst. At last, on the day of the Delaford picnic, I received the first news her. She was with child... and the blackguard who had--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Good God. Do you mean--Willoughby?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Before I could return to confront him, Lady Allen learned of his behaviour and turned him from the house. He beat a hasty retreat to London--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Yes! He left us that morning, without any explanation!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Lady Allen had annulled his legacy. He was left with next to nothing, and in danger of losing all that remained to his debtors--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: --and so abandoned Marianne for Miss Grey and her fifty thousand pounds.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Have you seen Mr Willoughby since you learned...?

Speaker: brandon
Dialogue: We met by appointment, he to defend, I to punish his conduct.

Speaker: brandon
Dialogue: We returned unwounded, so the meeting never got abroad.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Is Beth still in town?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: She has chosen to go into the country for her confinement. Such has been the unhappy resemblance between the fate of mother and daughter, and so imperfectly have I discharged my trust.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I would not have burdened you, Miss Dashwood, had I not from my heart believed it might, in time, lessen your sister's regrets.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I have described Mr Willoughby as the worst of libertines--but I have since learned from Lady Allen that he did mean to propose that day. Therefore I cannot deny that his intentions towards Marianne were honourable, and I feel certain he would have married her, had it not been for--for the money.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Dearest, was I right to tell you?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Whatever his past actions, whatever his present course, at least you may be certain that he loved you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But not enough. Not enough.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Here is someone to cheer you up, Miss Dashwood!

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: How is your dear sister, Miss Dashwood? Poor thing! I must say, I do not know what I should do if a man treated me with so little respect.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I hope you are enjoying your stay with John and Fanny, Miss Steele?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I was never so happy in my entire life, Miss Dashwood! I do believe your sister-in-law has taken quite a fancy to me. I had to come and tell you--for you cannot imagine what has happened!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No, I cannot.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Yesterday I was introduced to Edward's mother!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Indeed?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: And she was a vast deal more than civil. I have not yet seen Edward but now I feel sure to very soon--

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: There's a Mr Edward Ferrars to see you, Miss Dashwood.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Do ask him to come up.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Miss Dashwood, how can I--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Ferrars, what a pleasure to see you. You... know Miss Steele, of course.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: How do you do, Miss Steele.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I am well, thank you, Mr Ferrars.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Do sit down, Mr Ferrars.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: You must be surprised to find me here, Mr Ferrars! I expect you thought I was at your sister's house.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Let me call Marianne, Mr Ferrars. She would be most disappointed to miss you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Edward! I heard your voice! At last you have found us!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Forgive me, Marianne, my visit is shamefully overdue. You are pale. I hope you have not been unwell?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Oh, don't think of me--Elinor is well, you see, that must be enough for both of us!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: How do you like London, Marianne?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Not at all. The sight of you is all the pleasure it has afforded, is that not so, Elinor?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Why have you taken so long to come and see us?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I have been much engaged elsewhere.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Engaged elsewhere! But what was that when there were such friends to be met?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Perhaps, Miss Marianne, you think young men never honour their engagements, little or great.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No, indeed--for Edward is the most fearful of giving pain and the most incapable of being selfish of anyone I ever saw.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Edward, will you not sit? Elinor, help me to persuade him.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Forgive me but I must take my leave--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But you are only just arrived!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: You must excuse me, I have a commission to attend to for Fanny--

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: In that case perhaps you might escort me back to your sister's house, Mr Ferrars?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I would be honoured. Goodbye, Miss Dashwood, Miss Marianne.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Why did you not urge him to stay?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: He must have had his reasons for going.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: His reason was no doubt your coldness. If I were Edward I would assume you did not care for me at all.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Poor Miss Marianne looked very badly t'other day. When I think of her, deserted and abandoned, it frightens me to think I shall never marry.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Nonsense. You will marry far better than either of the Dashwood girls.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: How can that possibly be?

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: You have ten times their sense and looks.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: But I have no dowry.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: There are qualities which will always make up for that, and you have them in abundance. It would not surprise me if you were to marry far and away beyond your expectations.
