Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: I wish it might be so. There is a young man--

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Ah ha! I am glad to hear of it. Is he of good breeding and fortune?

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: Oh both--but his family would certainly oppose the match.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: Tush! They will allow it as soon as they see you, my dear.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: It is a very great secret. I have told no one in the world for fear of discovery.

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: My dear, I am the soul of discretion.

Speaker: lucy
Dialogue: If I dared tell...

Speaker: fanny
Dialogue: I can assure you I am as silent as the grave.

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Oh, my dears! What a commotion! Mr Edward Ferrars--the very one I used to joke you about, Miss Dashwood-- has been engaged these five years to Lucy Steele!

Speaker: mrs jennings
Dialogue: Poor Mr Ferrars! His mother, who by all accounts is very proud, demanded that he break the engagement on pain of disinheritance. But he has refused to break his promise to Lucy. He has stood by her, good man, and is cut off without a penny! She has settled it all irrevocably upon Mr Robert. But I cannot stop, I must go to Lucy. Your sister-in-law scolded her like any fury--drove her to hysterics.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: How long have you known?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Since the evening Mrs Jennings offered to take us to London.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Why did you not tell me?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Lucy told me in the strictest confidence.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I could not break my word.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But Edward loves you.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: He made me no promises. He tried to tell me about Lucy.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: He cannot marry her.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Would you have him treat her even worse than Willoughby has treated you?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No--but nor would I have him marry where he does not love.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Edward made his promise a long time ago, long before he met me. Though he may... harbour some regret, I believe he will be happy--in the knowledge that he did his duty and kept his word. After all--after all that is bewitching in the idea of one's happiness depending entirely on one person, it is not always possible. We must accept. Edward will marry Lucy--and you and I will go home.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Always resignation and acceptance! Always prudence and honour and duty! Elinor, where is your heart?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: What do you know of my heart? What do you know of anything but your own suffering? For weeks, Marianne, I have had this pressing on me without being at liberty to speak of it to a single creature. It was forced upon me by the very person whose prior claims ruined all my hopes. I have had to endure her exultation again and again while knowing myself to be divided from Edward forever. Believe me, Marianne, had I not been bound to silence I could have produced proof enough of a broken heart even for you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Oh, Elinor!

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Have I been rightly informed? Is it so?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: It is indeed so. Are you acquainted with Mr Ferrars?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: No, we have never met. But I know only too well the cruelty--the impolitic cruelty of dividing two young people long attached to one another. Mrs Ferrars does not know what she may drive her son to--

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I have a proposal to make that should enable him to marry Miss Steele immediately. Since the gentleman is so close a friend to your family, perhaps you will be good enough to mention it to him?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Colonel, I am sure he would be only too delighted to hear it from your own lips.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: I think not. His behaviour has proved him proud--in the best sense. I feel certain this is the right course.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Ferrars.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Miss Dashwood.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Thank you for responding so promptly to my message.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I was most grateful to receive it. I-- Miss Dashwood, God knows what you must think of me...

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Ferrars--

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I have no right to speak, I know--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Ferrars, I have good news. I think you know of our friend Colonel Brandon?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Yes, I have heard his name.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon desires me to say that, understanding you wish to join the clergy, he has great pleasure in offering you the parish on his estate at Delaford, now just vacant, in the hope that it may enable you--and Miss Steele--to marry.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Yes. He means it as testimony of his concern for--for the cruel situation in which you find yourselves.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon give me a parish? Can it be possible?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: The unkindness of your family has made you astonished to find friendship elsewhere.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: No. Not to find it in you. I cannot be ignorant that to you--to your goodness--I owe it all. I feel it. I would express it if I could, but, as you know, I am no orator.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You are very much mistaken. I assure you that you owe it almost entirely to your own merit--I have had no hand in it.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon must be a man of great worth and respect ability.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: He is the kindest and best of men.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: May I enquire why the Colonel did not tell me himself?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I think he felt it would be better coming from... a friend.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Your friendship has been the most important of my life.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You will always have it.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Forgive me.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Ferrars, you honour your promises-- that is more important than anything else. I wish you--both--very happy.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Goodbye, Miss Dashwood.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: What a stroke of luck for Lucy and Edward to find a parish so close to Barton! You will all be able to meet very often. That will cheer you up, Miss Marianne. I do declare I have never disliked a person so much as I do Mr Willoughby, for your sake. Insufferable man! To think we can see his insufferable house from the top of our hill!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I shall ask Jackson to plant some very tall trees.

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: You will do nothing of the sort.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I do not think she drew breath from the moment we left London. It is my fault--I should have found some other way of getting home.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: There was no other way you said so yourself.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: We shall be home soon enough. Mamma will comfort you, dearest.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I am stiff from sitting so long. Will you tell Charlotte that I am going for a stroll? ELINOR glances at the sky in concern.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I think it is going to rain.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No, no, it will not rain.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: You always say that and then it always does.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I will keep to the garden, near the house.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: We are very proud of our little Thomas, Colonel--and his papa has such a way with him...

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: There you are, Miss Dashwood! Mr Palmer and the Colonel have locked themselves up in the billiard room. Come and meet little Thomas. Where is Miss Marianne?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: She is taking a little air in the garden.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Oh, very good. That is the great advantage of the countryside--all the fresh air and... and all the fresh air...

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: He is the best child in the world-- he never cries unless he wants to and then, Lord, there is no stopping him.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I cannot see Marianne.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: She has probably taken shelter in one of the greenhouses!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Love is not love Which alters when it alteration finds Or bends with the remover to remove: 0, no! it is an ever-fixed mark That looks on tempests and is never shaken...

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Marianne!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Willoughby... Willoughby...

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: One thing is certain--she will be wet through when she returns.

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: Thank you for pointing that out, my dear. Do not worry, Miss Dashwood-- Brandon will find her. I think we can all guess where she went.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: She is not hurt--but we must get her warm!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I think Marianne may need a doctor.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You'll wear yourself out, Colonel! Do not worry! A day or two in bed will soon set her to rights!

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: You can rely upon Harris, Colonel. I have never found a better physician.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: What is your diagnosis?

Speaker: dr harris
Dialogue: It is an infectious fever that has taken far more serious hold than I would have expected in one so young. I would recommend the hasty removal of your child, Mr Palmer--

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Mrs Bunting! Mrs Bunting!

Speaker: mr palmer
Dialogue: My dear Miss Dashwood, I am more sorry than I can say. If you would prefer me to stay I am at your service.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mr Palmer, that is very kind. But Colonel Brandon and Dr Harris will look after us. Thank you for everything you have done.

Speaker: dr harris
Dialogue: She is not doing as well as I would like.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: What can I do?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Colonel, you have done so much already.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Give me an occupation, Miss Dashwood, or I shall run mad. He is dangerously quiet.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: She would be easier if her mother were here.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Of course. Barton is but eight hours away. If I make no stop, you may see us early tomorrow morning.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: In your hands I know she will be safe.

Speaker: dr harris
Dialogue: Double the number of drops and I will return as soon as I can.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Who is that?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Look, look, Elinor.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: There is no one there, dearest.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: It is Papa. Papa has come.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Dearest Papa!

Speaker: dr harris
Dialogue: I must fetch more laudanum. I cannot pretend, Miss Dashwood, that your sister's condition is not very serious. You must prepare yourself. I will return very shortly.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, Marianne, please try--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Marianne, please try--I cannot--I cannot do without you. Oh, please, I have tried to bear everything else-- I will try--but please, dearest, beloved Marianne, do not leave me alone.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: My mother!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mamma! She is out of danger!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: There, there, my love, my Marianne.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Where is Elinor?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I am here, dearest, I am here.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Colonel Brandon.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: Nor is the earth the lesse, or loseth aught. For whatsoever from one place doth fall, Is with the tide unto another brought...

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: 'For there is nothing lost, but may be found, if sought...

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Shall we continue tomorrow?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: No--for I must away.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Away? Where?

Speaker: colonel brandon
Dialogue: That I cannot tell you. It is a secret.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But you will not stay away long?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: There I fell, and there I first saw Willoughby.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Poor Willoughby. He will always regret you.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: But does it follow that, had he chosen me, he would have been content?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: He would have had a wife he loved but no money--and might soon have learned to rank the demands of his pocket-book far above the demands of his heart.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: If his present regrets are half as painful as mine, he will suffer enough.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Do you compare your conduct with his?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: No. I compare it with what it ought to have been. I compare it with yours.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Our situations were very different.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: My illness has made me consider the past. I saw in my own behaviour nothing but imprudence--and worse. I was insolent and unjust to everyone--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: --but you--you I wronged above all. Only I knew your heart and its sorrows but even then I was never a grain more compassionate. I brought my illness upon myself--I wanted to destroy myself. And had I succeeded, what misery should I have caused you?

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I shall mend my ways! I shall no longer worry others nor torture myself. I am determined to enter on a course of serious study---Colonel Brandon has promised me the run of his library and I shall read at least six hours a day. By the end of the year I expect to have improved my learning a very great deal.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: You'll go blind if you're not careful.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Is Thomas back from Exeter, Betsy?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am--he brung back two lovely fillets for you.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Beef is far less expensive in Exeter, and anyway they are for Marianne.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Sixpence a piece, Miss Dashwood. Oh, and he says Mr Ferrars is married, but I suppose you know that, ma'am.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Fetch Thomas to us, Betsy.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Beg pardon, Miss Dashwood, but they was the cheapest in the market--

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: It was a very good price, Thomas, well done. Would you be so kind as to build up the fire a little?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Who told you that Mr Ferrars was married, Thomas?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I seen him myself, ma'am, and his lady too, Miss Lucy Steele as was-- they were stopping in a chaise at the New London Inn. I happened to look up as I passed the chaise and I see it was Miss Steele. So I took off my hat and she inquired after you, ma'am, and all the young ladies, especially Miss Dashwood, and bid me I should give you her and Mr Ferrars's best compliments and service and how they'd be sure to send you a piece of the cake.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Was Mr Ferrars in the carriage with her?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am--I just seen him leaning back in it, but he did not look up.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Did--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Did Mrs Ferrars seem well?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Yes, Miss Marianne--she said how she was vastly contented and, since she was always a very affable young lady, I made free to wish her joy.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Thank you, Thomas.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Your father once told me not to allow you to neglect yourself. Now I find that it is I who have neglected you most.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: No, Mamma.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Yes, I have. We all have. Marianne is right.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I am very good at hiding.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Then we must observe you more closely.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Mamma?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Yes, my darling?

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: There is a painful difference between the expectation of an unpleasant event and its final certainty.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: 'At last I have found a small enough instrument to fir the parlour. I expect to follow it in a day or two, by which time I expect you to have learned the enclosed. Your devoted friend, Christopher Brandon.'

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: He must like you very much, Marianne.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: It is not just for me! It is for all of us.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Here is Colonel Brandon! Marianne!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: I do not think it is the Colonel.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: It must be. He said he would arrive today. You must play him the new song, Marianne.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Edward!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: It is Edward!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Calm. We must be calm.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Mr Ferrars for you, ma'am.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Edward! What a pleasure to see you.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Mrs Dashwood. Miss Marianne. Margaret. Miss Dashwood. I hope I find you all well.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Thank you, Edward, we are all very well.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: We have been enjoying very fine weather.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Well, we have.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I am glad of it. The... the roads were very dry.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: May I wish you great joy, Edward.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: I hope you have left Mrs Ferrars well?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Tolerably, thank you.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I--But EDWARD cannot seem to find any words.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Is Mrs Ferrars at the new parish?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: No--my mother is in town.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: I meant to enquire after Mrs Edward Ferrars.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Then you have not heard--the news--I think you mean my brother--you mean Mrs Robert Ferrars.

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Mrs Robert Ferrars?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Yes. I received a letter from Miss Steele--or Mrs Ferrars, I should say-- communicating the... the transfer of her affections to my brother Robert. They were much thrown together in London, I believe, and... and in view of the change in my circumstances, I felt it only fair that Miss Steele be released from our engagement. At any rate, they were married last week and are now in Plymouth.

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Then you--are not married.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Elinor! I met Lucy when I was very young. Had I had an active profession, I should never have felt such an idle, foolish inclination. At Norland my behaviour was very wrong. But I convinced myself you felt only friendship for me and it was my heart alone that I was risking. I have come with no expectations. Only to profess, now that I am at liberty to do so, that my heart is and always will be yours.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: He's sitting next to her!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Margaret! Will you stop--

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: What's happening now?

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Marianne!

Speaker: mrs dashwood
Dialogue: Oh! Is he? Oh!

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Your mother, I suppose, will hardly be less angry with Robert for marrying Lucy.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: The more so since she settled the money upon him so irrevocably--

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: --no doubt because she had run out of sons to disinherit.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Her family fluctuates at an alarming rate. Then, in London, when you told me of the Colonel's offer, I became convinced that you wanted me to marry Lucy and that--well, that you and Colonel Brandon...

Speaker: elinor
Dialogue: Me and Colonel Brandon!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I shall not forget attempting to thank him for making it possible for me to marry the woman I did not love while convinced he had designs upon the woman I did--do--love.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Would you--can you--excuse me--
